texts.definition: Pieces of game worlds that are owned by agents of those worlds.
markups: <style="Definition">Pieces of game worlds that are owned by agents of those worlds.</style>

Games with game worlds can have struggles over these worlds as part of their gameplay. This divides the game worlds into <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> owned by different players, possibly separated by wilderness, which become resources in the competitions or rivalries between them.
<style="H3">Examples</style>
<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> is probably the oldest game that concerns claiming <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> as one's own.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> and other grand strategy games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Axis%20&%20Allies">Axis & Allies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk">Risk</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hearts%20of%20Iron%20series">Hearts of Iron</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style>, all let players expand their domains by taking over other players' <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>. All but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Axis%20&%20Allies">Axis & Allies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk">Risk</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hearts%20of%20Iron%20series">Hearts of Iron series</link></style> also support the colonization of "wilderness" areas.

Having control over the steadily decreasing numbers of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Greed%20Corp">Greed Corp</link></style> is vital for winning the game.

The gameplay in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enemy%20Territory:%20Quake%20Wars">Enemy Territory: Quake Wars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Return%20to%20Castle%20Wolfenstein:%20Enemy%20Territory">Return to Castle Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory</link></style>, and in many cases the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> and  <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%20series">Team Fortress series</link></style>, can be described as team battles over <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Real-Time%20Strategy%20Games">Real-Time Strategy Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Command%20and%20Conquer%20series">Command & Conquer</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warcraft%20series">Warcraft series</link></style>, do ''not'' use <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> even if the core gameplay in these games revolve around controlling access to resources in the game worlds. The same applies for wargames such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advanced%20Squad%20Leader">Advanced Squad Leader</link></style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> is primarily used in games as a way of formalizing <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> in game systems. Inserting the <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> pattern in a game design requires that one provides ways of defining areas owned, why this is important for gameplay, and what players can do to change the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>. An alternative to <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> is to use <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> or a combination of both.

Assigning <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> is the typical solution for defining whom owns what part of a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20World">Game World</link></style>, be it <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> in grids of squares (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>), grids of hexes (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20V">Civilization V</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Greed%20Corp">Greed Corp</link></style>), or custom-shaped areas (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Axis%20&%20Allies">Axis & Allies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk">Risk</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> shows that the empty space between placed <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> can define <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style> than it suffices to only keep track of a few locations to structure gameplay.

The presence of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> imply that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> can change and that players can have <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. The reasons for these goals provide one set of design options regarding <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>. Besides simply having certain <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>, or control over a certain percentage of all <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Goals">Enforced Goals</link></style>, players can be motivated to seek control of parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> because they contain beneficial <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, or otherwise are <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>. Requiring control over <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> to access <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, either through what the <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> contain or by their inherent nature, is another reason to want control over them. Causing <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> to the common <style="Link"><link="health">Health</link></style> of enemy <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> or avoiding receiving it provides a motivation in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>. While <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> in themselves are usually passive game elements, they can instantiate <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style> (as for example done in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>).

How players should be able to <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> can be solved in several ways. Being the only player or <style="Link"><link="teams">Team</link></style> in an area is a common solution and links <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> to <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals; possibly after <style="Link"><link="camping">Camping</link></style> in the areas for some time to prove real control. This is also one way to make <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> important to <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> but having one may not automatically confer the other; Controlling areas in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Victoria%20series">Victoria series</link></style> do not give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of these, these are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> effects of peace accords. Likewise enemy <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can move through areas in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style> and pillage these but this does not confer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, e.g. sending settlers to areas in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> or "deploying" them in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>, are typically used to convert wilderness areas into <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> can formalize aspects of <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, e.g. access to <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style>, the two patterns can also work independently of each other. One example of this can be found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style> where <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> allow their owners to produce new <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> there by not if another player has <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> over it.

When <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> are <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> they can usually also be subject to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Naming">Naming</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>.
A special case of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> which has many design choices already implied is <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> often need to be presented in game interfaces, or rather, in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> themselves. This is typically done through having a colored overlay on the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and by being a form of <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widget</link></style> breaks <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> change <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> by dividing them into the domains of the players. Using <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> is one way of providing the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> pattern in games, and since very rarely the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> is permanent <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> also typically provide <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals. This is more likely if the <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> contain <style="Link"><link="location-fixed-abilities">Location-Fixed Abilities</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> due to being scarce (e.g. the supply points in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style>). Being game elements that can change <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> into <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, especially when they contain <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, but can also cause <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> choices of what <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> to defend.

<style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> can be used to define <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> even if they relate to parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> since these parts are not considered part of a player's <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>. Adding new <style="CurrentLink">Territories</style> can in these cards be a way to provide <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> and when this becomes the focus of gameplay <style="Link"><link="expansion">Expansion</link></style> phases come into being.
